content:
Yes, Eliza Gardner was the daughter of Marie Therese Raison de La Geneste Gardner and Joseph Gardner. She was born on June 1, 1831, in Barboursville, Cabell County, Virginia (now West Virginia), and was raised in a family of successful businesspeople.

Eliza Gardner went on to become an accomplished educator and writer. In 1850, she attended Miss Sarah P. Vose's Young Ladies' School in Boston, Massachusetts, and later taught at a school in Baltimore, Maryland. She also contributed articles and poetry to various newspapers and magazines, including the Anglo-African Magazine and the New York Tribune.

In addition to her literary pursuits, Eliza Gardner was involved in various social and political causes. She was a supporter of abolitionism and women's suffrage, and was involved in efforts to establish schools for African American children in the South. She was also a member of the Women's Loyal National League, which worked to secure passage of the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which abolished slavery.

Eliza Gardner never married and passed away on January 15, 1890, in Washington, D.C. She was buried in the family plot at Spring Hill Cemetery in Huntington, West Virginia.
